flags.title: User-Contributed Project
flags.text: This project guide is not managed by MAKE staff.

guide.introduction: Take a Intel LGA775 processor and make it into a keychain. I am making this guide because if you use a LGA775 processor, you will notice a very different design from the mPGA478 processors, and this may confuse some people on the procedure. Learn how to take a Intel LGA775 processor and make it into a keychain.
guide.introduction_rendered: Take a Intel LGA775 processor and make it into a keychain. I am making this guide because if you use a LGA775 processor, you will notice a very different design from the mPGA478 processors, and this may confuse some people on the procedure. Learn how to take a Intel LGA775 processor and make it into a keychain.

lines.text: Here we see the sacrificial CPU. This is a Celeron 420 1.6GHz single core CPU. It's too slow for anyone to want, including me. I don't want to toss it, so this is like a second life for it.
lines.text_raw: Here we see the sacrificial CPU. This is a Celeron 420 1.6GHz single core CPU. It's too slow for anyone to want, including me. I don't want to toss it, so this is like a second life for it.

lines.text: First, you will want to remove the heatspreader from the CPU. You will need a new razor blade to do this.
lines.text_raw: First, you will want to remove the heatspreader from the CPU. You will need a new razor blade to do this.

lines.text: First, get a razor blade and find a spot on the CPU to cut through and remove the heatspreader. Most Intel processors have a spot where there's no silicone you can stick this razor blade in to cut it off.
lines.text_raw: First, get a razor blade and find a spot on the CPU to cut through and remove the heatspreader. Most Intel processors have a spot where there's no silicone you can stick this razor blade in to cut it off.

lines.text: After you hit silicone, drag the razor blade across the silicone holding the heatspreader on the processor. This will be hard at first, so take your time at first. It will get easier as you cut the silicone.
lines.text_raw: After you hit silicone, drag the razor blade across the silicone holding the heatspreader on the processor. This will be hard at first, so take your time at first. It will get easier as you cut the silicone.

lines.text: Clean up the thermal paste from the dye under the heatspreader. This will improve adhesion when you rebond the heatspreader. Wiping it with a moist napkin will be enough in this case.
lines.text_raw: Clean up the thermal paste from the dye under the heatspreader. This will improve adhesion when you rebond the heatspreader. Wiping it with a moist napkin will be enough in this case.

lines.text: With the Intel LGA775 processors, there's no small hole in the dye to use as a drilling point, you have to pick where. Picking a spot that's balanced will be critical on these processors. I copied my mPGA478 keychain marking point and moved it a little to accommodate the heatspreader design.
lines.text_raw: With the Intel LGA775 processors, there's no small hole in the dye to use as a drilling point, you have to pick where. Picking a spot that's balanced will be critical on these processors. I copied my mPGA478 keychain marking point and moved it a little to accommodate the heatspreader design.

lines.text: Drill the hole in the heatspreader, then put it on the processor itself without the heatspreader in the same place.
lines.text_raw: Drill the hole in the heatspreader, then put it on the processor itself without the heatspreader in the same place.

lines.text: Putting the drilled heatspreader on without gluing it on can help you align it if you are having trouble.
lines.text_raw: Putting the drilled heatspreader on without gluing it on can help you align it if you are having trouble.

lines.text: Take some bathtub silicone or Liquid nails and put a generous amount under the heatspreader and silicone bead you cut to remove the heatspreader. Wipe the silicone or Liquid Nails that bleeds through off and let the silicone dry for 24-48 hours.
lines.text_raw: Take some bathtub silicone or Liquid nails and put a generous amount under the heatspreader and silicone bead you cut to remove the heatspreader. Wipe the silicone or Liquid Nails that bleeds through off and let the silicone dry for 24-48 hours.

lines.text: Put a computer ziptie on the processor and put your keys on.
lines.text_raw: Put a computer ziptie on the processor and put your keys on.

guide.title: Intel LGA775 processor keychain
